terminologie_extrait.terme: One gun is as good as two.
terminologie_extrait.definition: A common slogan in table tennis, referring to the dominance of forehand attackers in the past.

serve-and-forehand-loop.probleme: Developing a serve and forehand attack

debutant.description: Serve short, with the ideal third-ball attack serve bouncing twice on the other side and ideally an inch or so inside the end-line.
Serve to the backhand, forehand, or middle, varying the depth and spin to force the receiver to make mistakes.

intermediaire.description: Vary the spin of your serve, including backspin, no-spin, and sidespin, to make it difficult for the receiver to return.
Use left and right sidespin serves to change the trajectory of the receiver's return.

ready-stance.description: Stand with your weight on the balls of your feet, knees slightly bent, and relatively wide stance to be ready to move in either direction.

when-to-react.description: Move into position to attack before the receiver makes their shot, and be prepared for their return.

how-hard-to-attack.description: Make well-placed aggressive attacks that put pressure on the opponent and set you up for the next shot.

follow-through-back-into-position.description: Follow through back into position after your serve and forehand attack to be ready for the next shot.

mentality.description: Commit yourself to serving and forehand attacking, understand that proper preparation and reaction are key, and be prepared for the next shot.
